creator: matthewh8
title: Virtual Reality Flying Machine (Arduino)
description: This project converts a hammock into a VR flying machine. It uses a VR app running the WRLD SDK in Unity, allowing users to fly around a VR environment based on GPS coordinates. The hammock uses an ESP8266 to track leaning, which controls turning in the game. A fan, controlled by another Arduino, varies speed based on in-game speed. The project covers interfacing Arduino with Unity, wireless communication over WIFI, and variable speed fan control.
steps: Set up the fan by disassembling the shroud, removing screws holding the fan and motor, and unbolting the relay. Split the hot wire into three for each fan speed. Hook up the ESP-8266 to the fan.

Upload the provided fan code to the Arduino board, including your WIFI network name and password. Put the fan back together and zip-tie the relay to the back. Plug the fan into the wall and test fan speeds via the serial monitor.

Solder header pins onto the MPU-6050 and place it on a breadboard with another ESP8266. Connect two buttons to the ESP. Download the I2Cdevlib library. Navigate to Arduino->MPU-6050->Examples->MPU6050_DMP6_ESPWiFi and replace the script with the code in the following step and upload it to your board.
Upload the MPU-6050 code to the board.

Attach two pieces of wood to the hammock's crossbar. Screw the wood into the crossbar. Position the Arduino board as flat as possible. Spread the buttons approximately 1ft apart. Secure everything with zip ties and add a 5V USB power bank.

Attach the fan to the wood using its screw holes. If the crossbar isn't fixed, secure the fan with a rope tied to the top of the hammock. Prevent spinning by tying ropes to each end of the crossbar and anchoring them in front.

Download Unity 3D, download the GitHub repo from here:https://github.com/MatthewHallberg/flyVR. Unzip that whole folder and open it up in Unity. If you want to set it to something different click on the WRLD folder, API, and open up WrldMap.cs in visual studio. Change the latitude and longitude at the beginning of the script.

Build the VR app to your Android or iOS phone, ensuring it's connected to your WIFI network. Sit in the hammock, start the app facing the direction you want to move, plug in the fan and power banks, and let the system connect.
